This goes in the skimmer and floats to a vertical position when the pumps shut off to keep debris from floating back out into the pool.  It attached to a plastic housing that is mounted in the concrete in the ground.  
My pool was built about 15 years ago and I was unable to find a matching part anywhere. The old part was cracked and would not float and the hooks to hold in in place were worn out.  
The print worked perfectly.  Printed in Zentoolworks natural ABS with 3 shells all around and 10% honeycomb infill so that the thicker end would float...  
This is by far the largest flat surface I have ever even attempted to print.  210x130mm.

title: TIE Interceptor Lamp - Light up Stand

description.text: A new stand for DavidHanwell's TIE Interceptor (math derived from Al Meerow). The stand light ups the model and provides enough light to double as a lamp. You need to print the TIE model http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:103582 at 120%. In addition you need to print the battery box designed for this stand http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:344011

None of the prints require support 1) Print the TIE Interceptor model at 120%.
2) Print the battery box.
3) Print the stand and light mount/base
4) Cover the lamp base with Aluminum Foil (optional)
5) Wire a standard toggle switch and 12volt light together as shown in the picture. Make sure to put the wire through the lamp base or you might have trouble getting it in later (lesson learned). The 12volt light I am using is about 12mm diameter.
6) Install the switch from the top first.
7) Then push the battery box down into the stand from the top. I put mine in upside down and it catches on the toggle switch. I then use the bottom of the battery box to rest the light on (lifts it up just a little bit).
8) Put the light base and lamp on the top of the stand and add the TIE fighter.

title: Robo3D E3D Bowden Feed X Carriage

description.text: E3D Bowden Feed X Carriage for the Robo3D. It was designed for the V5. I started a thread for this in the Robo3D Forums here... http://forums.robo3dprinter.com/index.php?threads/donhuevos-e3d-bowden-fed-x-carriage.2555/

Print all without support. The upper housing has support material already added and easily removable with an Xacto knife. You should print the upper housing and anchor clip completely solid. The bearing channels will need extra TLC before you can press in the bearings. I used heatshield tape on the underside and a little inside the fan duct to reflect the LED's light. http://www.amazon.com/dp/B0051USC0E/ref=pe_385040_30332190_TE_3p_M3T1_ST1_dp_1 (The LED is stuck to the underside of the hotend fan with double-sided tape.)
The LED is a Neopixel from Adafruit. https://www.adafruit.com/products/1612
NOTE (6/9/2014): The X end-stop switch may need adjusted as the 40mm fan(s) may touch the case on tall prints. Also, when you home, if the extruder lands on the bed screw, the y end-stop switch may need adjusted as well.

comments.text: The most important thing to keep in mind is rigidity.  Once assembled, the extruder shouldn't be able to move at all within the carriage.  If you put your finger on the nozzle and try and move it, the whole carriage moves with it.

title: Sig P238 Grips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Grips for Sig P238. Use this to make colorful custom grips for your Sig P238. Use a free and easy to use CAD program such as Tinkercad to add custom touches such as your initials, then print it out. Enjoy!
Also, click on this link for a set of checkered texture 1911 grips: 3dPrintFileMarket.com. 3d Print File Market is not just another 3d printing website. You might be surprised to find that it is the home of The Original Technology Accelerator App that will change the world.

I discovered that the model's bottom is not completely flat. I've test printed it successfully at 0.2 mm layers without raft and at 0.1 mm layer with raft. However, do not print it out without raft at anything less than 0.2 mm layers. A future update will include a flattened bottom.

Added photo of my print. I used a children's CAD program, Tinkercad, to add my buddy's initials to her grips. I used a Makerbot Replicator Original with dual extrusion to print it out with custom initials on one side and a custom illustration of a dragonfly on the other side. You can do this, too, with your grips. Enjoy!

• Print this with supports.
  • Replace original grips.
  • Enjoy!

comments.text: It printed fine with 0.2 mm layers, but not with 0.1 mm layers because the bottom is not perfectly smooth. These were drawn in a CAD program but derived from a 3d scan. It fits my Sig just fine. I'll try to get a photo and post it.
comments.author: latigerlilly

comments.text: Interesting. Actually considering their small size and that you did use a 3d scanner, I'd say it did a pretty good job even if there is some noise.. Most 3d scanners I've worked with have trouble resolving much bigger features. What model scanner did you use?
comments.author: latigerlilly

comments.text: Unfortunately these don't seem to provide sufficient clearance for ambi-safety, I was hoping to print them even if the mesh looks noisy.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: As you can see with it mounted on my Sig, there is plenty of clearance for the safety. The mesh is not, "noisy". It is a textured grip, so it looks exactly as it is supposed to look. I would never put something online for others to print that is not printable and waste others' plastic.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: I was worried about the ambi safety, I see you provided clearance for the regular one. I wasn't trying to be hostile, but I just printed someone else's 238 grips and encountered that problem and yours look similar. It's such a small amount of plastic I don't mind trying it if you think it'll fit.
comments.author: latigerlilly

comments.text: No, I wasn't aware that the Sig P238 came with ambidextrous safety, if that's what you mean. You must've bought that or printed that as an aftermarket part as I have never seen one on a Sig P238 in any gun store. If you have a non-standard part requirement, I suggest you use tinkercad to cut one out of my grips. It is a free children's CAD program and is free.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: Haha even if I had the skills I'd be afraid to replace the safety with anything I printed.  I've seen them on a few, it seems they've added it to all of them recently.  The 238 and 938 I shot before I decided to go with the 938 both lacked ambi safetys.
comments.author: latigerlilly

comments.text: If you'd like, just mail me your sig p938 grips and I will design a grip for it with my 3d scanner and CAD program. I think I can just resize the grip, but when you resize the grip, the hole's dimensions will change, so after that, I will have to seal up the holes and then put new correctly sized holes in the original locations. I'll use my digital calipers to measure the holes and then make the holes just a tad bigger to account for ABS warp during the printing process. (0.3 mm bigger). The hole that is right on the print platform will be 0.4 mm bigger due to ABS ooze.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: Were these 3D scanned?  The mesh looks very 3d scan-like/noisy
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: I'll be interested in your 1911 grips. I've come across a couple of files here and there, but lack of texture makes them almost unusable and along with full size grips i need a set for a commander size frame and my attempts to modify the files i have have been less than successful.
comments.author: Ohio3wheels

comments.text: OK, I did a bit of Google-fu and came up with a discontinued pistol by Colt, the Commander had a 4.25 inch barrel and standard size grips, I think (I'm not sure).
comments.author: Ohio3wheels

comments.text:
I thought that there's only two styles of 1911; the full size and the officer's model, both of which have the same grip. The only difference is that the officer's model has a 1 inch shorter barrel. I have never heard of a "commander" 1911. I searched the Kimber and the Springfield websites and did not see a "commander" 1911. There were smaller 1911 style pistols such as the Sig p238, but they aren't real 1911s because they are .380 ACP or 9mm, but not 45 ACP. Please educate me as I have no idea what you're talking about. Thanks.
BTW, the grips that i'm designing and testing right now is for full size or officer's model 1911. Yes, the grips are textured.

These are protector caps for the common JST-XH balance connectors used on Lipo batteries.  These are designed a bit shallow intentionally so that the connector can't be pushed entirely on flush.  This allows the connector to be removed easier.  This is a work in progress,  unfortunately, these connectors do not have a lot of places to hook on to, so I am relying on an interference fit.  This means the tolerances of the print have to be pretty good.  In other-words,these might be hard to print and get a good fit.  You might have to play with scaling.  I have been able to get really good results as is with my solidoodle 4 printing at .3mm @ 40% infill.  Please report your results,

This lean, mean, ball-peen is ready for your general clobbering needs! And while it won't drive a galvanized nail into a pressure-treated fence-post, it will dutifully bludgeon interior nails, bang tight-fitting objects together, annoy individuals with experimental jazz percussion and acceptably intimidate others when held menacingly. UPDATE(s)! V2 - The peen has facets now to promote better printing at smaller scales and in general. sudo THWACK - a request from Vik, this is useful for executing "bash" commands. comments.text: Technically, a hypercube is more properly 'a tessarct', a cube within a cube, as represnted within 4 dimension space.
comments.author: dataman

comments.text: is not a tessarct just one shape in the hypercube family.  a tessarct is always 4 dimensional but hypercubes can be as many dimensions as you want.  Some super computers using as much as 12 dimensions(4096 processors)
comments.author: dataman

comments.text:
Remember, it's a shadow of a hyper cube, not a hypercube itself. Basically this is the equivalent of taking a cube, casting a shadow that looks like (http://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/~axs/fig/cube-only.png)http://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/~axs/...
and then looking at it as if you were on a two-dimentional plane (straight on if the shadow were raised)

description.text:
Since I have two different versions of the Alexmos board, I designed a case for both.  Neither if for the 32bit version.  The older one has capacitors and right angle connections for the motors.  
The OpenSCAD source files are included for each version.  
6/2/2014 - updated the OpenSCAD files to allow some slight customization for use on the QAV-500.  The case requires a notch out of the sides to allow it to fit between the forward most posts.  Orientation of the board will determine where the notches are placed and is selectable in the OpenSCAD file.

Printed in PLA with a .25mm layer height  
The bolt holes in the lower case don't go all the way through.  I did this on purpose so that no support was required due to the hex nut indents on the bottom of the case.  It just takes a moment with a 3mm drill bit to finish cleaning out the holes.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40703 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=40703

pattern_rotation = 14
case_thickness = 2.4
iphone_version = 1
pattern_thickness = 3
pattern_radius = 5
build_plate_selector = 0
pattern_shape = 3
Based on OhmEye MicroExtruder, configured to use 608 skate bearing and zenith HEC1063 corner brace along with other hardware I had at hand.

Based on OhmEye's extruder https://github.com/OhmEye/RepRap/tree/master/extruder geared extruder and hobbed drive from www.2engineers.com Local hardware had a different L bracket and as I had no 605's I altered this to suit 608'z and a slightly different fulcrum location. the extra plastic piece is to offset the mount hole for the L bracket to swivel on. Many have reported reliability issues with this geared drive, ensure fully greased up, and also watch acceleration. I believe the biggest issue lies in peak acceleration retract to extruder, causing tooth failure.. as per https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ft2PxD-q7aU

comments.author: 12much

comments.text:
Hey!
I really like this design.
We have problems, though, when trying to use the fans at less than 100% effect. It seems like the current to the fans create interference that messes up the temperature regulation. So if we set the fans to maybe 50%, the temperature is mistakedly read too high which makes the nozzle cool down, eventually leading to a failed printed. And there are no problems with 100% fan, it can't be that air is blown on the nozzle..
Anybody else having these problems and do you have any solution to it, other than maybe insulating the cables?
Thanks!
comments.author: ubsoknika

comments.text: So after finally getting the fans and trying these out, I have one important thing to say...DO NOT LET THE FANS RUN AT MAX...serious vibration issues, and more importantly my first too puffed smoke and died after i went to 165/255...partially my bad i went to the ebay link in the thing info and bought some of those, should known they were low quality when i read this line "Rated Current: 0.09±0.18 Amp"... so those burnt out, replaced them with 2 other fans of the same model and haven't taken those over the 135/255 mark...partially because they're loud and partially because I'm afraid of burning them out again. at that speed they don't really move too much air but long as it's a large enough print it seems to come out ok.  I think i'm going to try some alternative nozzles and hotends to try to get the printer working well for the tiny prints i really want to get printed...namely thinking some 0.18mm airbrush nozzles with a custom heaterblock could be fun (and the tiny nozzle size should help with getting fans closer and producing less radiated heat....sometime....when tools are available...eventually.

title: Razor Scraper Cover (EZ-Snap)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I really like AdanA's EZ-Snap Razor Blade Handle, but since I have pets in the house, I realized it wasn't a good idea to leave them just lying around. I came up with this cover after spending a few hours fiddling around in SolidWorks.   
It snaps onto the handle just like the handle snaps onto the blade: you insert the front into the groove then snap the handle down into place. When inserted, the bottom of the cover sits flush with the bottom of the handle, which makes it really easy to mount onto flat surfaces with just a little double-sided tape. I might make a version with holes or something for easier mounting.  
I've also included the original SolidWorks file in case anyone wants to fiddle around with it a little.

The print is pretty easy, since the entire bottom sits on the bed and there aren't any bridges or overhangs over 45 degrees. The only thing is that I tend to print the handles at a 102.5% scale to allow the blades to snap in more easily, so the cover fits those. If you have normal-sized handles, scaling to 97.6% or so should do the trick.   
For mounting, I just have it taped to the side of my Printrbot for easy access, but you can put it anywhere you want.

comments.text:
Yeah there is something that you are missing.
I completely understand how you feel about TakerBot and as a community we should punish them for trying to take what was in the public commons and make it exclusive.
With linux these kinds of discussions happened and if the decision had of been made to go non-commercial, then we would put governments in a position where they could never use open source operating systems. Government is going to be buying their services from someone, it's not just going to magically happen. The person that is going to be doing it will be profiting; will they profit from linux? their skill? their time? hmmmm. forget it. If you are an honest person that wants to follow the rules just exclude the IP that is restricted to non-commercial.
There were lots of linux distros. Some became very popular, others didn't. Some distro's lasted awhile, some were a flash in the pan. IP encumbrance is as much a factor as usefulness.
I have a 3d printer. I will print things for people. This costs me. It costs me my time, electricity and plastic. If I print your object for someone, can I recoup those costs? What if lots of people like your thing and now I am printing it many times, am I violating the non-commercial terms?
Ah forget it. Just don't favorite anything with that kind of encumbrance.
On the development side, people are going to be much freer with their ideas if you are free with yours. This thing is listed as creative commons with attribution. Fantastic. That's something that is worth helping with design ideas.

author: VintageTimeAustralia

description.text: A small, battery-powered gyroscope. Update (6/29/10): Here's a video of one in action. Note that I used 4 button cells instead of 2. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ov5WVhhIdWo Update (6/30/10): Added a DXF file for lasercutting. If you use 5mm stock, the result should be about the same. You'll need to drill out the pivot holes, though.

In addition to the listed parts, you'll probably need a few pieces of hardware for counterweights (to balance out the difference between the weight of the motor and the weight of the batteries). I used a nut and few washers I had lying around. Print flywheel and frame. Insert nails into holes in frame, glue in place and cut off excess. Attach flywheel to motor. Strap motor into inner disc. Strap batteries and counterweights to disc. Wire one lead of motor to batteries. Assemble frame - there are indentations where the nail points go. Attach remaining wire to batteries. It's a bit difficult to get the counterweights arranged just right. Wiring is pretty much just wedging one lead against either end of the battery stack. The motor I used was pulled from a toy gearmotor assembly (Solarbotics GM17 http://www.solarbotics.com/products/gm17). I left the pinion gear on the shaft to make mounting easier.

description.text:
Recycle Your tassimo capsules
This is a container for your used tassimo capsules. I figured out that instead og colecting them sending them for reused elseware, it was smarter to clean them chop them up and extrude them my self. This bin is for storing them until reextrution.

Print recycle pin
collect tassimo
Send them to support rainforest alliance OR
Rinse
Chup
Extrud into something like another tassimo bin. Note: When reusing plastic like this you might encounter that it can't conect to the previous layer.
If you reuse it several times it gets worse. SÃ¥ always mix new capsules with old former reused to keep your prints awesome. NEWS:Added A lid to keep the Keep it nice. The Lady is made out of tassimo ;-) Weird !!!! Maby i should offer her a cup of coffe. The re extrution are made with a engel industrial glue gun witch normal use glue in bloks. In goes the clean screded t pods out comes 1.75 +-0.05 mm filement ;-) Workes with anything that melts between 150-280 degrees C NEWS 23 Nov. 2012... The ideer just went to the final in the terra cycle contest. see the finalist here http://www.terracycle.dk/da/stemmeside

comments.text: You ever think of designing a refillable coffee pod that fits in the tassimo? To me, the only thing needed to be able to refil these things are a lid with the two holes in the right locations and 3 gaskets (one on the outer rim, and one for the input water, and one for the output water), and a good clamp so the lid doesn't leak. Heck - you could even possibly just print a lid ONLY that fit on existing pods. I have looked everywhere and can't find such a thing, you would be the first to make it. Heck I would buy it if it was on Shapeways!

comments.text: Would it really be that much weaker printed on a flat? Do you have the infill running diagonally as well?
comments.author: MakeALot

comments.text: If you place it at 45 degrees on the print bed then half the infill will go diagonally (depending on your settings).  Most of the stress is across the "elbow" of the bracket. having the layers of the print going the other way makes it much weaker as a bracket ( consider the levers attached to it), but better able to resist splitting from over tightening the screws.  Having said that, PLA, ABS & Nylon will all yield different results.  You should try printing one each way round in PLA and see how easy it is to snap.

title: Holiday Light clip for a porch railing

description.text: This clip holds holiday lights on my porch railing. I have a rounded porch railing cap and got tired of unwinding the lights from the rail in the cold. I designed a clip that fits over the rail so I can just unclip to remove the lights.

Print the number of clips you need.
Clip on your rail.
Install lights.
Plug in the lights and enjoy.

comments.text: The clips fit my rails perfectly as you can see in the picture. I printed some for a friend and his rail was slightly larger. My rail is 65.5mm. his rail was about 75mm so I simply scaled the print in my slicer program to match his rails.

3D Snowflake

• Design the object in Inventor.
  • Then bring the image to Autodesk 123D Make and deside how many layers and how many pieces that hold it together you want.
  • Once the design is done convert it so that it can be edited in illustrator.
  • Next try to fix all of the pieces on the smallest number of pieces of cardboard.
  • Print to a epilog laser with the settigns of vector speed of 40, vector power of 100 and vector frequency of 500. The cardboard thickness is around 3/16 of an inch.
  • put the model together

We have an old magnetic dart board that has half the darts missing, but the game is still fun, so why not make new darts?
This is no longer a work in progress.  These things came out great!  Nice feel in the hand.  Nice weight distribution.  Good flight characteristics... better than the originals!
I'm biased, of course, but I recommend making these if you have a magnetic dart board.  Oh heck!  Go out an buy a magnetic dart board and replace the darts with these! :-)

The fins come out from the body at an aggressively acute angle. You'll need to blow on the print to hasten cooling of the ABS as this part of the fins are being extruded. Once it gets past that lower part of the fin, all is good. Blow on it or it will be ugly. You have been forewarned. :-) These darts use a 3/8" x 3/8" cylindrical rare earth magnet in the tip. Make sure your cavity will be a very snug fit for the magnet. The size of the magnet I chose was for the front end weight needed. I initially tried a smaller magnet and a slug from a nail, but believe me, it's a whole lot better just using a bigger magnet. :-) Worth saying twice: Make sure your cavity will be a very snug fit for the magnet. These magnets have a lot of pull. You can glue them in, I guess, but you already spent money on magnets. Save the money. Save some ABS and make the socket snug. 10% fill
.27 layer height (the ridges serve as a grip... feels nice in the hand)

This is a derivative of my previous Raspberry Pi enclosure that ditches the light pipes and bolt together design for an easier to assemble case with strong durable Delrin clips to hold everything together. It's got fewer parts than the previous case and it's been designed for compatibility with Adafruit's Pi Plate prototyping board. Many of the mods to this new version where contributed by Thingiverse user RoboLemur. UPDATE:
This design has been updated to support both models of the Raspberry Pi board (A and B), with custom sides for each and a better standoff design.

Features:
  • Compatibility with the Adafruit Pi Plate and Cobbler kits
  • Fewer parts and easier to assemble than the previous version
  • Strong, durable Delrin clips hold everything together nicely without having to juggle nuts or worry about snapping parts by over tightening bolts and everything comes together with a very satisfying "snap"
    • Cut the black lines and etch the red lines. Clips are 1/8" Delrin, the new standoffs are 3/32" Delrin, and all other parts are 3mm (1/8") acrylic. More pics and full assembly instructions on my blog here:
    http://www.built-to-spec.com/blog/kit-instructions/clear-raspberry-pi-enclosure-assembly-instructions And I've made kits availiable in my store here:
    http://builttospecstore.storenvy.com/products/745661-clear-raspberry-pi-enclosure-kit

description.text: Sobreporca Carenagem YBR

Update 19/08/2014
Added improved filament spool holder and disc and also a wiring grommet for where the cable bundle from the hot end and extruder stepper pass through the Z tower extrusion. The hole in the extrusion should be drilled 180mm from the base of the Z tower stepper mount. This allows full travel on the Z carriage with the 225mm rods (tube length) that I use with the 8mm drilled ball bearing and spring/string retention system. I normally drill two 5mm holes adjacent to each other and file the bridge between them out to form an oval. I've also added some detailed assembly images and a drawing that shows where the T nuts in the lower base are required.
Update 08/08/2014
I've changed the design of the delta rods. Instead of using magnets I am now using 8mm stainless ball bearings drilled with a 4mm diameter, 4mm deep hole. They are sold for some sort of use in photography. Readily available on ebay. The effector and rod carrier designs have been changed so that they have 8mm sockets to accept the 8mm balls. The whole thing is locked together with Spectra line (100lb) and springs. I used 85mm, fairly strong ones. A little silicone grease before assembly should stop any wear. I've uploaded the amended .stl files and some images of how I assembled it all. There is also a write up in my thread on the Reprap forum. It really does make a rock solid, backlash free connection between the effectors and the towers. There is absolutely no play at the nozzle and I've been able to up 'quality' print speeds considerably.
Anyone that has followed my previous designs has probably been expecting this :-) I've now got to a point where my Cherry Pi printer is at iteration three and I'm really happy with it. Version III incorporates mini V wheels for the carriages and a hot end Z probe for auto levelling and calibration. I use Rich Cattell's Marlin fork which enables all that. I have managed to substantially reduce the number of parts required and, due to the v wheels leaving the rear face of the extrusion free, been able to mount te extruder to the Z tower which results in a relatively short Bowden tube to the extruder. I have renamed the plastic parts to incorporate details of the quantity required and the settings and materials I used to print mine (P=perimeter, B=bottom layers, T=top layers). I've also switched to using a centrifugal fan as I feel it gives greater airflow. It's also easier to incorporate into the Z probe hot end design. The print areTa is around 190mm x 190mm x 250mm. I print at 100mm/s infill, 60mm/s outer perimeter, 70mm/s inner perimeter and 200mm/s travel. Acceleration is 3000 throughout and XY Jerk is 20. It would probably go higher but I'm happy at that and it doesn't seem to stress the machine too much.
BOM
Plastic parts as required
3 x 2020 Bosch/Rexroth Extrusion @ 600mm
9 x 2020 Bosch/Rexroth Extrusion @ 250mm
6 x 16mm x 5mm x 4mm flanged bearings
9 x Open Builds Mini V Wheel Kits
12 x 10mm spherical neodymium magnets
6 x 6mm aluminium tube (with 5mm ID, I drilled mine to this) @ 225mm
12 x M5 8mm SHCS machined with a 10mm ball end mill to form cup for magnet (rod ends)
4M GT2 belt
3 x GT2 pulleys
4 x 13mm x 6mm x 7mm micro switches
4 x NEMA 17 stepper motors
1 x Arduino Mega 2560
1 x RAMPS 1.4
1 x RRD Smart LCD Display
4 x 4988 stepper drivers
12V 5A PSU
Mains lead
1 x 50mm brushless centrifugal fan
250mm diameter glass/mirror build plate
J Head (Bowden type)
0.5M 4mm OD 2mm ID PTFE tube
2 x 1/8 NPT 4mm pneumatic fittings
5 x 608 bearings (extruder and spool holder)
100mm M8 threaded rod (spool holder)
M8 60mm hobbed bolt (hobbed at 25mm)
3 x M8 nut
8 x M8 washers
2 x M3 50mm SHCS (extruder clamp)
2 x compression springs to suit above
2 x tension springs to suit effector/hot end hinge
8 x M3 nut
3 x M5 45mm SHCS (top idlers)
3 x M5 nut
6 x M5 washer
18 x M3 8mm SHCS (stepper fixing, effector)
2 x M3 30mm SHCS (effector/hot end hinge & fan mount)
3 x M3 25mm SHCS (carriage adjuster)
2 x M3 15mm SHCS (effector springs)
61 M5 T-Nuts (i use these http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28788)
61 M5 8mm SHCS
Apologies if I missed anything but I think it's mainly all there. Let me know.
Enjoy

comments.text: Yes. The trick your missing is to drill a hole through the Z tower extrusion from front to back. I normally drill two 6mm holes very close to each other to form an oval. Take the heater, thermistor, fan, Z min, etc cables around the back of the Z tower and then through the hole just below the Extruder back to the front. The wires fit nicely in the front slot of the Z tower and I cover them with either 2020 cover strip or vinyl tape

comments.text: Make sure the steppers are a the top of their slots. Pull the belt into a loop without the screw to lock it and then turn the screw into the belt loop with a driver. This should get it pretty tight. Then slacken off the stepper screws and push them down to really tighten. My belts 'twang' when I pluck them. The material is carbon fibre effect vinyl. Just google it. It make a great print bed surface for PLA on a cold bed. I print at 210 and it sticks great.

comments.text: The dimensions of the carriage are definitely correct. I've personally built 8 Cherry Pi III printers and several people around the world have also completed successful builds. Check out the thread here http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?178,361141http://forums.reprap.org/read.... it may help if you can post some images of your printed parts and the extrusion you are using. The carriage is designed for the mini V wheels from Openbuilds and the extrusion needs to have a V slot. Normal T slot won't be suitable unless you re-design the carriage to allow for the lack of the V
comments.author: tiffyted

comments.text:
I have started my build. I had a similar issue with the spacer rubbing a bit on the roller bearings for the carriages. Once I figured out the best combination of spacers/washers for the bearing it turned out great.
The only thing I had to change was how the rod holder portion connects to the wheel carriage. Originally, as I tightened up the tension it would skew the rod holder. This was because the two screws holding the rod holder to it were on the side that has only one v wheel. Once I modified it so that the rod holder was held to the carriage with two screws on the "two v-wheel" side and one on the "one v-wheel" side, then I would get no skew as I tightened it up. It stays pretty much square.
I'll post a remix with a few small changes once I get done. This is a really nice design Andy. Thanks.

comments.text:
Hi ekaggrat
All the parts shown in the images of the printer were printed on a Cherry Pi (Cherry Pi II). The speed and quality are great. I use Cura and set the base print speed at 60mm/s, the outer perimeter at 45mm/s, the inner perimeter at 50mm/s, and the infill at 80mm/s with a 33% infill and 0.3mm layer height. My machines use a 0.4mm nozzle and I normally print PLA at 210 degrees C. The only part that is different is the effector I print that on another machine that has a heated bed and use ABS with a 0.2mm layer height.
I built a 3DR when it was first released, it was a good machine but I had issues with the filament drive spools where the filament overlapped all the time and threw the steps per mm off slightly. Could this be your issue? I also wanted a machine with a larger print bed. Cherry Pi III uses a 250mm diameter bed and I get, more or less, 200 x 200 x 250 build area.
Andy

title: alternative Prusa refitting set, variable size

description.text:
What this Set of parts is for:
  • easier size-modulation for 3D Printers
  • Alternative Structure Materials of the frame
  • Adjustable printer and bed levelling, to make it work on every surface, no matter if its perfectly leveled

As you can see, i used aluminum beams for it, but everything else should work, if it provides enough strength. I already thougt about unsing wood, with some further reinforcements, but nothing tested yet.
the z motor mounts can be placed inwards, so that the thickness of the vertical beams isnt an issue for the x-axis, but then be shure that there is enough space to the printbed for the z-stabler. This modification could also have an effect on your available z-height.
the x-axis is all from prusa, thats why i marked it as derivate from it. I did this because i had trouble constructing a reliable x-axis, and my prusa parts worked nearly perfect. So you can use yours, or choose whichever are marked as prusa compatible. for extended x-range i'd recommend 10mm rods.
same for the z-couplings, i used mine, findable within my things
To change the size, just shorten or lengthen the beams, rods an belts. All the other parts will work fine on it.
If you change the thickness of the beams, be shure to mount the y-axis parts at the upper edge, to ensure the bed going above the beams.
If some people are interested i can give a complete hardware parts list, and some formulas to calculate the needed rod an beam lenghts for a desired printable size. (these informations would take a bit of time, of which im actually short of)
Feel free to modify, derivate or whatever, there's plenty of space for improvement in these parts. If .skp files are needed, let me know, i can up them aswell.
skp files from all parts and the printer to see where the parts belong.
one more thing:
as y axis bearings you can use what you prefer, i used prusa ones

title: HDD Rail for Medion/Digitainer HTPC case / Schiene 3.5 inch

description.text:
For my new computer setup, I chose the cheap â‚¬15 Medion/Digitainer HTPC-Case
from Pollin. It's a surprisingly well made case with screw-less drive mount... IF you have the parts, which are not included for a 3.5" Harddrive. After considering mounting the drive under the DVD burner, but beeing unhappy with the 5.25" to 3.5" adapters I could find, I started one myself. I tried to keep it minimalistic (cheap&fast), but I did not finish it (See SketchUP file: Test_HDD_5-25_3-5_Adapter3.skp). Instead I decided to create slides for the intended harddrive bay, and after finding some similar one at Google Warehouse that did not work out, I started from sketch.
I somewhat cleaned them up and made them a single manifold object, plus changed it so they can be printed without support material from one side.

The spacer-STL-Part sticks into one of the slots (not identical, so try which one fits), and keeps the rail in place vertically, too. The initial version's fit was VERRRRY tight, I included a (untested) SLIM version (about 0,4mm thinner).
Also note that the plastic rail is not reaching to the bottom of the drive, what some may prefer instead of sliding the drive on the bay directly. You will need to increase the part height (upper printing side) half a millimeter or so. Have fun!
PS: See screenshot for best printing orientation on small beds. PPS: Don't wear as earring.

A nice Tyrannasaurus skeleton project. I have printed mine to make a nice desktop model. I'm going to upload the photos as soon as possible. But I'm sure you find better way to use it. Good luck.

All parts were named, numbered and signified which one belongs where. Also you'll find complete T-Rex model which you can figure out which part should come together with which one. When printing parts, be patience and take a notes. I also uploaded blueprints which have specified parts name on it. Technically, I've glued mine with cyanoacrylate adhesive but failed. If you print these models out of PLA, I recommend using "Hot Melt Trigger Glue Gun" which can be found commonly in local stores or follow the links below; http://www.amazon.com/Melt-Trigger-STICKS-EVERY-ORDER/dp/B0002KR9DY http://www.amazon.co.uk/Stanley-070416-STHT0-70416-cordless-Glue/dp/B006XBSNQ8/ref=sr_1_17?s=diy&ie=UTF8&qid=1401268983&sr=1-17 http://www.amazon.fr/Dremel-Pistolet-b%C3%A2tons-temp%C3%A9rature-F0130910JA/dp/B00439G4ZE/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1401269174&sr=8-2&keywords=pistolet+%C3%A0+colle+chaude Actually I didn't have a chance to print this with ABS. So, I can not say which glue is better with ABS.

title: TicTacToe
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As a kind of Warmup for the use of the RWTH Aachen-Fablab ( http://hci.rwth-aachen.de/fablab ) we've made a little tictactoe game. Rules are wellknown, so there's no need for a description: Three of a kind in a row, diagonal or in column wins, and if nobody makes a mistake, this would be no-one.
Looks nice, but the fun of playing a no-win-game is a little bit limited, instead it's like lego: More fun with building than with playing :-)

Logic and Electricity: We use as pawns in the game for the two player stereo jackets with a red or green led within. One contact is used for both player as common contact, the other two are used to differentiate between red and green.
(If we are sometimes be able to go back in time: It would be much easier to work with a mono jacket, and use a series resistor in the jacket for the differentiation between the two colors) In the gameboard the female connectors are connected with a arduino. The shared contact between red and green is connected with one I/O-pin for every single connector, while the all "red" contacts are parallel connected with one common I/O-pin, "green" contacts analog.
All these pins are generally used as output to light the leds, but the two "red" and "green" pins are switched periodic to input-pins for a read-out of the gameboard occupancy.
(Memory for the time-travel: In this case we will also connect one contact of each connector to one I/O-pin, but the other all together with one analog input and with either HIGH or LOW (depending of the leds) over another series resistor. The gameboard occupancy can easily be readout with the analog input. Of course, only one connector at each time, but fast enough not to be seen) The computer player use another 6 pins of the arduino for his led-matrix, the standard connect the one led-contact in three rows and the other in three columns for all leds, and ready. Three Pins are still unused: One for the switch between computer and human adversary, another two connected with leds for the next-player-display.
Something import forgotten? Yes, playing the game: For this purpose, we use the reset button. Start the game - or not now, maybe some kind of enclosure would be nice! The Box: First of all: The electric circuit described above and shown in the FoodForEagle (guess, for which program these files are :-) or in "the circuit.pdf" can of course be etched or milled.
We have simply cut another piece of wood with the lasercutter and wired all the parts (not so simple :-). The FoodForTheLasercutter.pdf printed with a Lasercutter (black lines are for cutting, red for engraving) gives also four sides, which can be glued to the above mentioned board with all the electric parts. We used some kind of 4mm-multiplex-wood, which was a little overkill, but we can use our game (even with cap and base only plugged) to adjust tables, wardrobes or defend ourselves :-)
At the end, sandpaper all edges, polish the whole box and etch the wood (or use a wood, which looks nice without etching). The cap and base is only plugged, which makes access for removing the arduino for another device, build in a batterie and repair bad wirings or soldings (which, of course, never had happens :-) easy.
(Only if the device stands upright as shown in the pictures for Front and Back, gravitiy wins and a crack appears). (Another TimeTravelMemo: Use thinner wood as mentioned before, and make the box bigger: Our first design was for the 3D-printer, which made the box as small as possible for cost purposes. A bigger box would made the whole wiring more comfortable, and we could use a batterie with a proper jacket - in our box we have to solder the batterie wires direkt to the arduino, because we have no place for a jacket.
Another minor mistake was a copy and paste of the sides without the cuttings for the intermediate bottom, but thanks to a good glue, the remaining cuttings at the edges an the 4mm it's still stable :-) To be honest: you can also make the whole box easy with a coping saw or even as a paperbox with scissors and a printer. But it looks much better in this wood-with-engraving-look. The first design was a plexiglasfront with a 3D-printed box, but the test-printing for that with the lasercutter at cardboard looks so great, that this early design was cancelled and we switched to the wood-version.
And as I mentioned at the beginning, the fun is the making and looking and not the game itself.

comments.text:
Great project!
Wood was a great choice for this game.

description.text: Heart charms that can be linked together in different ways, i.e. like a bracelet, a necklace and even a ring from one closed charm. They come in different sizes, some are closed, some have an opening on the side and some on the bottom. Makes nice jewelry.....
Made in 3D Game Studio, saved as a prefab, converted into a 3DS file and finally made into an stl file by Adobe's CC student version

Ã˜3 ID Ã˜5 OD washers.
place shims under the corners, to adjust height to level the bed. Use combinations to get the height correct. Once its level in Y, you should be able to adjust X using Z adjustment.

Print, measure, adjust using appropriate combinations of washers
0.1 Layer height, 0.1 first layer.
If you can't print first layer at 0.1 due to bed not being level enough, you need to adjust your Z heights by hand, in X. It is not so critical that your Y heights are spot on, as it is quite a small print. I have added another set, to print at outers of the bed, at 1.2mm high.
This is more forgiving of poor setup, you can print at 0.4mm layers, 0.4 start, and you end up with a 1.2mm (+/- that corner's variance from level) washer for each corner of your bed. In doing this print I found only my back right corner to be out of level, by 0.2mm so I added a 0.2mm shim printed from my first batch, bed is now level!

comments.text:
The Printrboard has a limitation of about 10,000 pulses per second. If you are using the GT2 belt with 80 steps/mm that equals a theoretical max speed of 125mm/s. If you use this and double your steps/mm to 160, than you are limited to a theoretical max speed of 62mm/s.
The benefit of moving to 1/4 step instead of 1/16 step is to reduce the pulses per second and increase the possible max speed. If you had 80 steps/mm @ 1/16 step, and then changed to 1/4 step you would have 20 steps/mm (500mm/s based on board output, but motor can't do it). At 20 steps/mm you can just start to make out the steps in the print surface. By using this mod and doubling that resolution than you have 40 steps/mm (250mm/s possible) and good print quality!
The unfortunate situation with the small Kysan motors (depending on your model) is they can't really run reliably over about 40mm/s, just not enough torque. I have changed my Y axis to a large Kysan, and am about to do the same to the X. My machine was a 2013 version, so I don't know what size motors the 2014 models have.
comments.author: kwintberg

comments.text:
Purchased Simple in 2014, it's supposed to be a 2013, I think it's a 2013.666r.
Anyway, It came with three big (1124090) and one small (1124101) motors. The small one was placed on the Z-axis, but when I did the y-Axis no-sag thing, I swapped the Y and Z motors, it ran much quieter after that. I had a print where I had to increase the Z-hop, to .4mm, as some little/thin legs kept getting knocked over, the Z-hop helped, and the small motor coped fine.
To the question. To alter from 1/16 step to 1/4 step, is it a case of cutting the motherboard, or is there a software option do you know? I have followed your discussion on the forum 'Change 16X Mircostepping'. Just wondered if there was a developement I had missed. Will this mod loose some of it's benifit, if we don't do the moherboard snip?
Thanks for taking the time and trouble sharing, your great designs.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text:
Looks like the figured out the motor limitations after my 2013 version, that is very good!
To answer your question, yes it is a physical board jumper hack to change from 1/16 to 1/4 micro-stepping. Not that hard at all, and I have solder-jumpered and changed back and forth several times, so it is not permanent.
Loss of benefit with no 1/4 microstepping? Well that would depend. If you are currently printing over 60mm/s than you may have to slow down a bit. You mentioned the noise. With the higher motor speed (160 steps/mm) it runs much quieter and smoother!
If you want to push the speed envelop, than 1/4 micro-stepping and double precision will get you there. If you DO want to push the speed, the XL tower (or some equivalent) is required. The Z rods are just not stable enough to support the high inertial loads of higher speeds.

After my heavily-used kitchen sink strainer fell apart for the second time in five years (see third gallery picture) I decided to make a shower-type strainer that fits into the drain cup where the strainer basket normally sits. While this doesn't give me the option of letting water collect in the sink (a possible future option), it should be sturdy and able to handle boiling water, heavy pots getting plopped on it, etc.  
There's a gap of about 5mm on the sides which I'll fix in the next revision. Note that the normal way to fix this is to remove the plumbing tail underneath, remove the cup assembly, and install a new cup assembly using plumber's putty. This was a bit easier.  
I also find that strainer baskets don't really work that well for me - it's just as easy to collect rubbish from the bottom of the sink using a sponge, and having a flat sink bottom makes this easier.

Printed using 3mm ABS, with 0.3mm layers - nothing fine-grained about this. The strainer part should be on the heated bed and the slope up to the open end should be gradual enough not to cause any overhang problems.

A teaching aid for explaining the operation of an autogyro/gyrocopter.
A simple rotor head which uses one or two plastic rulers as a crude aerofoil.
I haven't gotten it to auto-rotate yet and maybe it won't - it is experimental.
This is not intended to ever fly. I don't know what the critical things are to achieve auto-rotation that is partly why I've made this. Obviously making a windmill is easy but that problably isn't the same thing. I'm lacking a good wind source for testing ATM.
My current feeling is the blades will need to be sanded to a better shape.
This is a very low priority project so it may take some time. There seems to me to be contradictory information on the web regarding blade pitch. It looks like slightly positive pitch is the norm for fixed pitch rotors.
http://www.faa.gov/library/manuals/aircraft/media/faa-h-8083-21.pdf
Shaft bearing assembly to follow. http://www.jefflewis.net/autogyros.html#workings Update1:
I tried the zero pitch rulers in front of an industrial fan and seemed to get some auto-rotation.
It was weak and the swirling uneven air-flow may not be causing true auto-rotation.

gyrorotorholder.stl is a zero-pitch ruler mount. gyrorotorholder3.stl has a 3 degree pitch. This has to be printed standing end on. gyrohead.stl has holes to take a 3mm pin or something to act as a teeter bolt. Ideally we'd stick some bearings there but first try will just be a lubed pin. cy1.stl is a clark-y aerofoil.
cy-sim is a symetrical foil based on the clark-y
cy-sim-pair has two joined foils for printing stability. The also have some mounting holes.
naca8h12-pair uses a common profile used on real gyrocopters.
naca8h12-pair-ccw is a mirror image so it rotates the same direction as big gyros - it may need a reversed hub.

comments.text: A windmill definitely is not the same as a gyro rotor. One thing you need to know is that a gyro does not start autorotating when it is not rotating yet.
comments.author: thingyman

comments.text:
Not quite. Yes I've pre-rotated all along.
The last profile I posted is a gyro profile.
No you need positive pitch - usually 1 to 5 degrees. It it wasn't positive they couldn't do stop and drop landings.
The airflow is usually up except during prerotation and landing flare.
comments.author: thingyman

comments.text: Would i be wrong in thinking that blade twist is a critical part of autorotion?
comments.author: araspitfire

comments.text:
Â I'm not an expert in gyros. I've never flown one or had a close look for quite a while. I read some theory and watched a lot of video. I don't think real gyro blades have twist or taper but they are proper airfoils and possible have non-zero pitch (possibly even negative pitch). I haven't found that information anywhere.
(Even when set to zero pitch you get positive pitch when you tip the rotor back and move forwards).
I think the important thing is the retreating blade stalls near the hub.
I've only tried the rulers in front of a fan which is too weak and not a laminar flow.
I also don't think the teeter bolts is needed for auto-rotation but I could be wrong.
comments.author: araspitfire

description.text:
I finally came up with an extruder I am happy with. Open design, easy access for cleaning, loading, unloading, etc. This version will mount to my 300mm No Sag upgrade.
I have been running this on my machine for a few weeks now and I couldn't be happier. Have not tested with the Ubis hot end. It will fit, but I am not clear about the amount of heat that transfers up to the mount. This works very well with an E3d hot end.
I re-used the spring and screw from my stock Printrbot wood DDE.
My spools sit next to my printer so I also included the filament guide I am using that attaches to the 300mm No Sag bearing plate.
Poor documentation, so any questions please feel free to ask. 2014-06-24: Added a front end version "JL-DDE-Simple-Double.stl" to work with the Double Precision mod: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:344822 2014-07-28: Uploaded a revision to the extruder to remove the cantilevered bearing post. "JL-DDE-Simple-Double-2014-07-28.STL" & "JL-DDE-Simple-2014-07-28.STL". This should help eliminate bearing alignment issues if the part experiences any warping from extruder motor heat.

title: Steampunk Couture: CNC Goggles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I started this project long, long ago. I was teaching at TechShop and had the time, tools, and a drive to make something serious. You see, I have had this long history of mixed emotions about steampunk. On the one hand, it is a wonderful and beautiful to look back on generations past and reflect on all the awesome things they have done. It is great to be inspired by Tesla and Grahm Bell and all the guys slaving away in steel mills wearing top hats. On the other hand steampunk has also become a label for hastily made shoddy things muddled together with hot glue, watch gears, and brass spray paint.
Often times my philosophy is to not have opinions on things until I have done something substantial to justify them. This is me putting my money where my mouth is. This is my highly engineered, hard labor, meticulously calculated answer to why steampunk is awesome. There can be so much cool in the intersection between math and metal and leather and science and I think everyone should give it a try.
The whole set of photos from the project is on display here http://www.flickr.com/photos/gianteye/sets/72157624394079042/
You can see a bit more on how the metal components on the goggles were made here http://www.flickr.com/photos/gianteye/sets/72157619078382624/ and find out a bit more about the prototyping process here http://makersmarket.com/seller/gianteye/blog
I fuel my insatiable love for design and adventure through ventures like selling digitally fabricated jewelry on etsy. You should take a look at http://gianteye.etsy.com or get in touch with me at m sinbox.org if you have ideas, advice, job offers, commissions, or cake.

Cutting
First you need some leather. I got mine laser cut from ponoko ( http://www.ponoko.com/showroom/gianteye/steampunk-couture-goggle-leather-pattern-4567 ). They use a 2.5mm thick natural leather that was perfect for this project. If you cut your own out, make sure to cut your leather suede side down with something adhered to it to keep the leather from shifting due to the heat. I will often use a piece of printer paper stuck on with a light coat of spray adhesive. Transfer paper also works well for this purpose. The laser cutting leaves a decent amount of soot around the edges, so I cleaned everything off with rubbing alcohol before dyeing and conditioning the leather.
Dyeing
The black parts of the leather were dyed with a water based leather dye, and the white parts were actually painted with an odd little container of tennis shoe whitener I found at a pharmacy. I softened the leather with Neatsfoot Compound, but almost any leather conditioner/softener/oil will do. I left everything to dry overnight so there would be less of a chance of dye rubbing off on my thread as I stitched everything together.
Fastenings
Refer to the PDF I have included ( http://www.thingiverse.com/download:10190 ) for details on where your fastenings shall go. The snaps are pretty simple to figure out and should not cause mutch of a fuss. The buckles and Dee rings are also fairly self explanatory.
Sewing
I felt like I went through miles of embroidery floss. My fingers ached and I was covered in tiny needle inflicted holes by the end of the process. The hardest part is keeping the feeling in your fingertips long enough to stitch up the whole thing. It is important to remember to stitch the eye cups (the circular parts that attach to the goggle hardware) together before attaching them to the mask.
Hardware
If you own a CNC machine you will know what to do with the stls. Otherwise, you might consider getting your own set of goggle hardware printed here http://www.shapeways.com/shops/gianteye (the gold plated stainless steel seems like a pretty excellent option). Print out a Left Hand Body, a Right Hand Body, two Front Plates, and a Nose Bridge. You will need to assemble your 3d print with the 6-32 self tapping screws I have specd.
Lenses
Be sure to remember to cut yourself out a set of lenses. They're simply 1.6" dia circles cut out of .11" acrylic. You can also find a set of patterns here http://www.ponoko.com/showroom/gianteye/eyepieces-for-steampunk-couture-goggles-4568 I used 2 way mirror stock from Tap Plastics. It worked out great, but it is incredibly easy to scratch off the thin mirror layer. Be careful when handling it.
Good luck. I hope this helps you in drafting out your own digital fab projects. I've tried to include everything I can to help people through making their own goggles, but this is by no means a complete tutorial. I am, however, hoping it provides a strong framework for you to experiment with your own digital designs and maybe even your own kickass steampunk styles.
Thank you.

An evolution of emmett's razor blade handle. 
Excellent for removing prints from the build platform.
-tweaked the fit to work with the single-edged razor blades I'm most familiar with (Stanley #9?). Key to a forgiving fit was the full cutaway under the corners. 
-added unnecessary but fun flourishes like radii and chamfers

I printed at 0.123mm/layer, which gives an even multiple for the bottom sheet feature. I don't know if it's critical.
I've printed versions at 32% and 50%. 32% seems plenty strong. 
If necessary, X-acto trim under the corner overhang details. I found that, by rotating it to the 45Â° position in which you see it here, I got much cleaner bridges there and trimming was unnecessary.
Consider filing/sanding the blade corners to reduce digging into the HBP cover (Kapton, etc.).
Consider dulling the blade ever-so-slightly. I've found that the first blade I had in the Emmet version of this works much better than new ones I tried in my updated model. New blades will just dive down into the Kapton if your holding angle isn't perfect. Presumably the only difference is time-related dulling.
Please do not try to force the fit - you may slip and cut yourself, or the blade may snap and harm your eyeballs or other sensitive things.

title: Double Precision Y GT2, Printrbot Simple

description.text:
This is an extension of my 300mm No Sag, that converts to double precision. Check the notes on the source MXL Double precision about speed limits.
I am running this on my machine since early May 2014, but have converted to 1/4 microstep instead of 1/16 microstep. This allows me greater speed and keeps the quality.
I am short on time so the documentation is poor. Any questions please feel free to ask and I will comment when possible. 2014-07-03: I have converted back to 1/16 microstep (stock) and running 100mm/s with 160 steps/mm and have not hit the limit of the Printrboard. I no longer believe 1/4 microstep is necessary for 100mm/s. It may be required to print faster, but that is still untested water. 2014-06-03: Just noticed the rear clamp was oriented incorrectly for printing. Corrected and re-uploaded.

Hi again,
Finally got all the parts printed out and assembled for this mod and the Double Precision X GT2, so now I'm at the part where I'm supposed to cut some jumpers on the circuit board in order to change it to 1/4 microstep... and I'm a little fuzzy on how to do that. I found an article on Printrbottalk where you and RetireeJay were discussing what to cut in order to change the stepping amounts... and I think I'm supposed to cut where this post indicates: http://www.printrbottalk.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=21&t=6040#p38906http://www.printrbottalk.com/f...
So... am I correct? Or is this going to cause Additionally, I see on the board that there's sections labeled MS-X, MS-Y, MS-Z, and MS E... so will cutting the solder at MS-X only change the microstepping in the X axis? Will I need to cut the MS-Y one as well?

comments.text: Update...I have been printing using a 160 steps/mm, 1/16 micro-stepping, and running 100mm/s without any issues.  I no longer believe the Printrboard is limited to 10,000 steps/sec as this configuration is outputting 16,000 steps/sec.
comments.author: pemling

comments.text:
That is the spot to cut. You can always jumper it back with a blob of solder, but cleaning off the coating enough to solder it back is a challenge. I have gone back and forth several times.
You are also correct about the MS-X, MS-Y etc. They are all independent so what you do on one does not affect the others. MS-X for the X axis, MS-Y for the Y axis, etc.
Good luck!

My New Simple Makers Upgrade Kit is "processing" so I cannot confirm or deny anything at this point. Once it arrives I will review and update compatibility with my designs here.
It looks like they have incorporated many of the key features required for reliable printing. I would suggest learning your new machine, get familiar with it, and then upgrade once you really get a good feeling for the limitations of the stock machine.
Getting into the world of 3D printing is very exciting, and very challenging. It is still much of an "art" and all machines be it Makerbot, Printrbot, or other, need constant attention and tweaking to function long term. I would highly recommend connecting with http://printrbottalk.comprintrbottalk.com for all issues Printrbot.

comments.text:
Hi,
Glad I saw this and the X axis one you posted! I was planning on printing/constructing them over the weekend, but looks like I'll have to do a little more reading before I begin. I'm kind of new to all this and have a few quick questions, if you have time.
I have an un-modded 2014 model (with the aluminum extruder, if that helps), but it looks like the front piece of this mod (ExtendYFront2013FanDouble.STL) is designed around the 2013 model... so I'm curious if I can use one of the front pieces from the regular GT2 mod of yours (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242185)?http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... Or is this design really only supposed to be used with that new extruder design you just posted (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:344748)?http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
Oh, and I'm assuming that I'll also need to make the ExtendYPlate.STL part (or the ExtendYPlateRevC.STL part, if I'm right in thinking that's the most recent iteration) to put this version together, correct? Are there any more parts from that version that are needed for this one? I have similar concerns about the X axis one (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:344678);http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... are there any parts from the previous version that I'll need to make as well?
Thanks for doing all this cool work!
comments.author: pemling

comments.text:
You will need this ExtendYFront2013FanDouble because it houses the bearing to create the double precision. Your stock wood plate that the 2014 aluminum extruder mounts to should fit with one exception. You will need to notch the back corner in order to clear the bearing.
Yes you will also need the ExtendYPlateRevC and new linear rods. Good job on the research, I have been lax on my documentation. That should be the only thing you need for the Y. I think they changed the Z screw mounting on the 2014, so look at the options there on the 300mm no sag posting. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242185http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
For the X, you will need the motor plate and bearings from the GT2 X thing. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:194686http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
Keep in mind, changing the X motor plate is basically a complete tear down of the machine so just be prepared. Some people are surprised how far down you have to dig to get that plate out.
comments.author: pemling

author: sgalvin

title: The Cube: A Cathedral Game Piece

description.text:
**Note: I just added a second version with larger steps. The smaller steps were not visible on my printrbot simple. This is yet another Cathedral game piece to mix things up.
This piece replaces either of the 2 Square pieces (made of 4 squares). The thing that makes this piece so interesting (especially in reference to this game) is the history of the actual building (Grande Arche) and a book called the Cube and the Cathedral.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grande_Arche The philosophy behind the Grande Arche (the Cube) is humanitarianism and the philosophy behind the Cathedral is theism. If one is not familiar with philosophy in general, then one may fail to see the stark contrast between these two ideas. For you, I leave you 2 wikipedia articles and the book referenced above.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanitarian
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theism
http://www.amazon.com/The-Cube-Cathedral-America-Politics/dp/0465092683 For those who do, I have only to say...enjoy! But be careful which side you choose!

For Printing:
believe it or not I printed this piece with no support on my PrintrBot Simple. I had no major issues.
quality = .3 (feel free to change as needed)
Fill = 25% standard
Not sure that any of the above settings matter, but people are always asking so... For Playing:
This is yet another Cathedral game piece to mix things up.
This piece replaces either of the 2 Square pieces (made of 4 squares). Square (uppercase) - referring to the square shaped piece made of 4 smaller squares.
square (lowercase) - referring to the small squares that make up the board. ***The below is now complete and uploaded. I removed the original. I will be creating a version of this piece soon that will fit around the spaces on the original plastic board. Currently the bottom is just flat.
I may also add some more detail to this piece as time goes on. The current piece was just a quick mock-up.

author: benblur4

description.text:
An informational booklet that can be printed and handed out to students and 3D-printer beginners to help them understand the basics of the 3D printing workflow and community. The individual pages were designed in Photoshop, then put together into a booklet using InDesign. I designed this booklet specifically for undergraduate Art students at my university, but using the source files you can easily modify the booklet to work for your workshop or institution. Table of contents:
  • What is 3D printing?
  • How does it work?
  • What can I do with 3D printing?
  • Overview of the 3D printing workflow
    • The 3D printing workflow
  • Get a 3D model for printing
    -- a. Downloading a model
    -- b. Designing your own model
  • Preparing and slicing the model
  • Printing the model on the Replicator
  • Finishing your prints
  • Resources for learning more
  • Inspirational people to watch

Print the booklet using InDesign
I prefer to print these booklets as 2-up saddle stitch booklets using InDesign. Print double-sided to create a compact booklet that can be folded and stapled. Follow the instructions here for more: http://help.adobe.com/en_US/indesign/cs/using/WSa285fff53dea4f8617383751001ea8cb3f-704ba.html Print the booklet from PDF
After designing/tweaking the booklet in InDesign, you may not want to go through the hassle of working with it to print additional copies. Export a PDF in InDesign, then follow these instructions to print a booklet: http://helpx.adobe.com/acrobat/kb/print-booklets-acrobat-reader.html

comments.text: We made this the official workbook of our 3D printer and design meetup at Freeside Atlanta.  We couldn't print them fast enough.  The blank notes section was a priceless addition for people sitting through the lectures and such.

author: noelwclarke

title: Rotor mount for GoPro style action cameras

description.text:
Rotor mount (helmet mount / swivel mount) originally designed for GoPro Hero 3+ action camera with Ultra wide FoV. The rotor mount was designed to be easily taken apart into pieces that fit into carry on luggage and can be easily taken apart and reassembled without tools on ski lifts etc. (Simply pull the aluminium poles from the sockets, they are being hold together by elastic cord)  
WARNING! Attaching this (or any pole for that matter) to your helmet will dramatically increase the risk of severe or fatal head and neck injuries! Use at own risk!  
When crashing with the thing, it is supposed to crack at the base and/or the aluminium fitting - but don't count on it!

To complete this build you will also need:
2 aluminium tubes, ÃÂ16x500mm (ÃÂ10mm indent on one end)
2 closed ball bearings (608?) (rollerblade/skateboard type) inner ÃÂ8mm, outer ÃÂ22mm, 7mm width.
1 bolt: M8x40
1 nut: M8
5 washers, inner ÃÂ8mm
1 bolt: M6x40
1 nut: M6
1 washer ÃÂ6mm
2 bolts: M5x45 (standard long GoPro mount screws will do)
2 bolts: M5x30 (standard long or short GoPro mount screws will do)
4 nuts: M5
1 meter elastic cord (ÃÂ3mm)
100-200g of lead pellets to counter weight of camera (fill dummy GoPro)
1 GoPro style action camera
1 GoPro style helmet mount
1 GoPro base (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53438) The design was done using Autodesk Fusion 360. The assembly video was to be done by using Autodesk Fusion 360 Publisher Beta, but it was discontinued. Assembly video will probably be released, when Publisher goes live again. I printed mine on the Solidoodle 4 withe the all new extruder.
Black ABS (1.75) 0.1 layer height, 205C nozzle, 110C bed with glass plate and glue stick applied.

comments.text: Dear Kumy, the Hex is 12.80 mm to accommodate a standard M8 Hex head. I have printed 3 rotor mounts and they fit perfectly. However there is no room for error, you need to print at a 0.1 resolution. If you print your first layer at say 0.2 (common) you may have to trim the edges using an exacto knife, to make the M8 Hex head fit. If you print at, say 0.4 resolution, and your printers extrusion is a bit off (extrudes too much ABS), it would explain your print being off by 1mm?
